question: Which of these is the best password?
options: password123
ilovepizza
B!rDs4ReGr8
qwerty
description: A strong password should have a mix of letters, numbers, and symbols.

question: What should you do if a website asks for your home address?
options: Enter it if the website looks fun
Only share it with friends
Ask a parent or trusted adult before entering it
Post it on social media to check if it’s safe
description: Never share personal details online without checking with an adult.

question: Why should you log out of your accounts after using a public computer?
options: So no one else can use your account
Because the computer will explode
To make the computer work faster
Because the website asks you to
description: Logging out stops others from accessing your account without permission.

question: What does the padlock symbol in the browser bar mean?
options: The website is safe and protects your information
The website has fun games
The website is for kids
The website is asking for your password
description: A padlock means the website is using encryption to help keep information private.

question: Which of these websites is safest to use?
options: www.cool-games.biz
www.learnwithschool.edu
www.freemoney-now.com
www.videosforkids.net
description: Websites ending in .edu are for educational purposes and are often safer.

question: A message says you’ve won a prize but need to enter your details to claim it. What should you do?
options: Enter your details quickly before you lose the prize
Ask a parent or teacher before doing anything
Click the link and see what happens
Tell your friends about it
description: Many online messages about winning prizes are scams. Always check with an adult.

question: Who should you share your password with?
options: Your best friend
No one except a trusted adult
Everyone in your class
People you play games with online
description: Only share passwords with trusted adults to keep your accounts safe.

question: What should you do if someone you don’t know messages you online?
options: Reply and see if they’re nice
Ignore them and tell an adult
Send them a picture of yourself
Ask them for their real name
description: If a stranger messages you online, don’t reply—tell an adult.

question: Why should you think before posting a picture online?
options: Because you can’t delete it once it’s posted
Because it might use up internet data
Because pictures take up space on the internet
Because people might copy your photo
description: Anything you post online can stay there forever, even if you delete it.

question: Which of these is an example of personal information?
options: Your favorite food
Your birthday and home address
The name of your pet
Your favorite TV show
description: Personal information includes details like your birthday, address, and phone number.

question: A friend asks for your login details to use your game account. What should you do?
options: Give it to them since you trust them
Tell them to make their own account
Post it in a group chat so everyone can play
Write it down on a note and pass it to them
description: Never share your login details—even with friends. They should make their own account.

question: What should you do if a game asks for your real name and phone number?
options: Enter your details so you can play
Make up fake details
Ask a parent or teacher before entering anything
Tell your friends and ask what they did
description: Some games collect personal information. Always check with an adult first.

question: Why should you check if a website’s address starts with ‘https’?
options: It means the website is about technology
It means the website has extra security
It means the website has a password lock
It means the website has fun games
description: Websites with ‘https’ use encryption to help keep your information safe.

question: You see a mean comment about a friend online. What should you do?
options: Ignore it and move on
Reply with a mean comment back
Tell a teacher or a trusted adult
Join in and laugh
description: If you see something hurtful online, report it and tell an adult.

question: What should you do if you see something online that makes you feel worried, scared, or upset?
options: Tell a trusted adult, like a parent or teacher.
Keep it a secret and try to ignore it.
Click on lots of buttons to see if it goes away.
description: If something online makes you feel uncomfortable, always talk to a trusted adult.

question: How can you tell if a website or a video is safe for you to look at?
options: It has bright colours and fun pictures, so it must be safe.
A trusted adult has checked it or it has a child-friendly symbol.
If it loads quickly, then it must be okay.
description: Trusted adults or child-friendly symbols help show what’s safe for children.

question: Why is it important to ask a grown-up before searching for something online?
options: Some websites or videos might not be suitable for children.
Grown-ups don’t want kids to use the internet.
You might break the internet if you search for the wrong thing.
description: Asking an adult helps keep you safe from unsuitable or harmful content.

question: What kind of information should you never share when searching online?
options: Your name, address, school, or phone number.
Your favourite colour and the name of your pet.
How many times you’ve been online today.
description: Personal information like your name or address should always be kept private online.

question: If a website or game asks for your name or address, what should you do?
options: Type in a funny made-up name instead.
Ask a trusted adult before sharing any personal details.
Give them your real name because websites always keep secrets.
description: Always ask an adult before giving any personal details online.

question: Who are the trusted adults you can talk to if you see something online that doesn’t feel right?
options: Your parent, teacher, or another trusted adult.
A stranger online who seems friendly.
No one – just keep it to yourself.
description: Talk to a trusted adult if something online doesn't seem right.

question: What should you do if a pop-up appears on a website asking you to click on something?
options: Close it and tell an adult if you’re unsure.
Click on it quickly so it goes away.
Type in your name and email so you can get a prize.
description: Pop-ups can be unsafe, so always close them and check with an adult.

question: Why do some websites have 'child-friendly' symbols or safe search filters?
options: They help make sure the content is suitable for children.
They are just there to make the website look pretty.
They let anyone, including strangers, send you messages.
description: Child-friendly symbols help show that the content is safe for kids.

question: What could happen if you click on a link or a video without checking first?
options: It could take you to something unsafe or inappropriate.
It will always be something fun to watch.
Your computer will automatically delete all your games.
description: Clicking random links can lead to unsafe or inappropriate content.

question: How can you help a friend who has seen something online that made them feel uncomfortable?
options: Tell them to talk to a trusted adult.
Ignore it and pretend it didn’t happen.
Keep watching or playing to see if it gets better.
description: Encourage friends to speak to a trusted adult if they’re upset by something online.
